content.text: So far we've focused on **deductive** arguments, where valid forms guarantee the conclusion. **Inductive** arguments are different - they make the conclusion probable, not certain.

content.definition: An argument where the premises, if true, make the conclusion probable but not certain. Even with true premises, the conclusion could still be false.
An inductive argument that applies a statistical generalization to a particular case. From 'Most Fs are G' and 'x is an F', we conclude 'x is probably G'.

content.title: A Statistical Syllogism
premises: 90% of students who study regularly pass the exam.
content.conclusion: Therefore, Maria will probably pass the exam.
content.note: This is NOT deductively valid - Maria could be in the 10% who fail. But the argument is inductively strong.

symbols.name: Certain Conclusion
symbols.example: All A are B, x is A, so x is B

symbols.name: Probable Conclusion
symbols.example: Most A are B, x is A, so x is probably B

content.text: Inductive strength is a matter of degree. An argument with 95% support is stronger than one with 60% support. We evaluate inductive arguments by how probable they make the conclusion.

content.question: What makes an argument inductive rather than deductive?
options: The conclusion could be false even if all premises are true
It has more than two premises
content.explanation: The defining feature of inductive arguments is that the premises support but don't guarantee the conclusion. Even with perfectly true premises, the conclusion might still be false - it's just made probable, not certain.
